VOL. XX, NO. 28.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 22, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HOPKINS WINS SECOND PLACE

ST. JOHN'S NINE VICTORIOUS

'VARSITY WINS BOTH MATCHES

FOOTBALL SCHEDULE ANNOUNCED

Track Team Finishes After B. A. A. in
South Atlantic Meet-Hall and Connolly Capture Championships.
Straus Next Captain.

Wins Last Baseball Game of Season,
After Hard Struggle, by Score of 2
to 1-Phythyon Pitches Well
for Johns Hopkins.

Defeats University of Michigan by Score
of 4-2 and Georgetown University
6-0-Hopkins Men Show
Fine Form.

Presents Few Changes From That of
Last Year-M. A. C. Game to
Take Place Again on
Thanksgiving.

The Baltimore Athletic Association captured the team trophy in the
games held by the South Atlantic
Division, Amateur Athletic Union,
on Homewood Field last Friday,
Hopkins taking second among the
ten organizations represented. The
Baltimore Athletic Association had
a very large number of competitors
entered under their colors, and with
he stellar work of their "giant"
Tommy McDonagh, supported by
a large number of lesser satelites,
they piled up 47 points while Hopkins was making 34. In the longer
runs Hopkins had a decided advantage, but their opponents'
strength in the hurdles and weights
gave them the lead.
McDonagh was easily the star
of the meet with 19 points to his
credit, made in five events, but Connolly of Hopkins also earned his
share of glory, taking part in six
events, hurrying back and forth accross the field so as not to miss
his turn at anything, and securing
places in five contests with a total
of ii. It was "Husky's" last appearance for Hopkins, ending a
career of four years' faithful work
and consistent point-winning.
Two records of the Association
were smashed and one equalled in
the afternoon's performance, not
to speak of a new Hopkins mark
being set in the half-mile run. In
the last-named event, Hall went
out at a pretty good clip from the
start, his tracks being closely followed by Chipman of Maryland
Agricultural College, who kept the
Hopkins man up to his pace. The
time, 2 minutes I 2-5 seconds, is
four-fifths of second better than the
old mark, set by E. S. Woodruff,
a graduate student, in 19oo.
Tommy McDonagh was responsible :for disturbing two low
marks. In the high hurdles he
cl:pped a fifth off, by covering the
ground in 15 3-5 seconds, and in
the low hurdles he equalled a
former performance by tearing
through in 25 4-5. A third association mark was upset by Weidman, Georgetown's sensational
pole-vaulter. After raising the
standards by th use of some hurdles, and putting the bar on the
very top .of the posts, he cleared
12 feet with a terrific leap.
After the meet, which is the last
on the schedule for the season, the
team elected Harry Straus, '17,
captain of next year's team. Straus
has been a hard worker for three
years at Hopkins, and prior to that

With both pitchers in rare form
and pitching' air-tight ball, St.
John's was just barely able to nose
out Hopkins 2 10 I, at Homewood,
on Saturday afternoon. The game
was exceptionally fast, Captain Ewing's work around third base and
on the paths being the feature of
the game.
In the first inning Hopkins
scored. Ewing's speed was responsible for the only tally made by
the Black and Blue during the
game. He drew a base on balls,
and then stole second. Tucker's
error of Hobbs' easy grounder gave
Ewing a chance to go to third.
Then the Hopkins captain and
Hobbs pulled a double steal, Ewing being safe at home and Hobbs
resting securely on second.
St. John's won the game in the
second inning. Freeny and Polk
each drew a base on balls. Then
Siebold threw the ball over the
second baseman's head in his attempt to prevent the men from
making a double steal. Freeny
took home on the play. Elzey then
came across with a long two-bagger
and Polk ran home with the winning run.
The rest of the game was hardfought, but resulted in no scoring.
Ewing stopped a St. John's rally
in the eighth by making a beautiful catch of Burgess' liner and
doubling up Elzey at first. Again
in the ninth, Ewing brought the
spectators to their feet by running
over to the fence and catching Jarman's foul.
In the ninth inning Hopkins had
a chance to even up the score.
Howell took first on Freeny's error
and then stole second. The Hopkins rooters had their hopes raised
for a few moments, but Siebold
fanned at three of Tucker's curves,
making the third out.
If Hopkins had won this game
it would have given them a good
claim on the state championship,
but as it is, St. John's has won this
honor from Hopkins for the first
time in years.

The Johns Hopkins tennis team
added two more victories to its list
by defeating the University of
Michigan and Georgetown teams
on Friday and Saturday respectively.
During the first part of the
Michigan match it seemed as if the
visitors were going to have an easy
time of it, but a brilliant rally by
the Hopkins men succeeded in turning the tables and resulted in a 4
to 2 victory for the 'Varsity. The
GeorgetoWn match was easily won
by Hopkins, the score being 6 to O.
The scores of the matches are as
follows:
Hopkins vs. University of Michigan, 4-2.
Singles-Allan beat Crawford, 8-6,
6-4; Mack beat Taylor, 6-2, 6-3; Sweitzer beat Hammond, 6-1, 6-3; Jacobsen
beat Sherwood, 3-6, 6-0, 6-4.
•
Doubles-Hammond and Taylor beat
Mack and Crawford, 1-6, 6-3, 6-4; Jacobsen and Stroebel beat Sweitzer and
Sherwood, 3-6, 6-3, 6-2.
Hopkins vs. Georgetown, 6-0.
Singles-Allan beat O'Boyle, 6-4, 6-0;
Taylor beat McGuire, 6-1, 6-3; Hammond beat Karesey, 6-3, 6-2; Jacobsen
beat Reynolds, 6-4, 6-1.
Doubles-Hammond and Allan beat
O'Boyle and Karesey, 6-4, 7-9, 8-6; Taylar and Jacobsen beat McGuire and
Reynolds, 6-4, 6-4.

The football schedule for next fall
has been definitely announced by
Manager Davis. Since last fall,
rumors have been spread broa‘dcast that some of the big college
teams would be seen in action on
Homewood field during the 1916
football season, but these rumors
have been without foundation.
Hopkins will play practically the
same teams this year that it did
last.
The management is of the opinion that before Hopkins should attempt to move up the scale into the
realm of the big college teams, it
should have at least another season's experience against local teams.
In other words, the management
does not want to book games with
the big colleges until it feels confident that the Black and Blue can
make a good showing against them..
As soon as Hopkins has successfully shown to all its permanent
superiority over the Maryland
teams, no time will be lost in arranging games with the best teams
in the East. As was the case last
year, the Maryland Agricultural
College will be seen at Homewood
on Thanksgiving Day, and St.
Johns will be played the Saturday
before Thanksgiving: All the
games of the season are to be
played at Homewood.
The schedule:
October 9, Mt. St. Mary's.
October 16, Washington College.
October 21, Gettysburg.
October 28, George Washington.
November 4, Swarthmore.
November II, Western Mary
land.
November 18, Haverford.
November 25, St. Johns.
November 30, Maryland Aggies.

JOHN C. KNIPP RE-ELECTED
BUSINESS MANAGER

. At a meeting of THE NEWS-LETTER Board on Monday, May 15,
John C. Knipp was re-elected Business Manager for the coming year.
Mr. Knipp has been associated with
THE NEWS-LETTER for over three
years, and has had long experience
in the business administration of
the paper.
With this meeting, the resignations of Frederick K. Bell and G.
Franklin Ludington, both of the
Class of 1916, went into effect.
These men were both elected in
February, 1915, and for over .a
year have rendered valuable service as associate editors.

DEBATING COUNCIL TO LET
TRIANGULAR AGREEMENT WAIT

Although it was at first thought
advisable to have the triangular debating agreement between this
University and the Universities of
North Carolina and Virginia signed
this year, the Debating Council has
informally decided that, in view of
the extremely friendly relations between the three institutions which
four years of debating contests
have brought about, the annual
compact can wait for formal ratification until next season.
At Class Day, the eight members
of the two victorious teams of this
year will be presented, with the
blue "H," the official Hopkins
award for debating.

HULLABALOO TO BE OUT JUNE 1
Final Proofs Have Been Corrected, and
Book Now Ready for Pre!s—Business Staff Waging Subscription Campaign.

The 1916 Hullabaloo will appear
on or about June 1. The first proofs
for the book are already in the
hands of Editor-in-chief Tingley,
and the business arrangements for
the payment and distribution of the
issue are rapidly nearing completion.
In its final form, the Hullabaloo
will have nearly 300 pages. The
dummy for the entire issue has
long ago been made and presented
to the printer, and the reading of
proof was the last stage in the editorial work. This reading came to
end on last Friday morning, and
the time before the book is issued
will now be measured entirely by
the period required for the mechanical processes of making corrections,
running the forms off the press,
and binding the separate sheets.
Judging by the proofs, this year's
Hullabaloo will be one of the best
ever produced by a Hopkins class.
It is highly original, both in arrangement and in material; the
art work is of an exceptionally high
caliber; and, even in the imperfect
appearance presented by unbound
sheets, the contents of the book
promise to be unusually interesting,
not only to the members of the
Senior Class, but to the University
as a whole.
The business staff is now busily
engaged in collecting the debts still
outstanding, and in taking every
possible means to guarantee a large
circulation. Every member of the
graduating class has already subscribed for at least one copy, many
of them for more, and a large number of underclassmen have signified their intention of buying the
book. It is in the support of the
latter element that the Hullabaloo
is now particularly interested. The
edition is to be strictly limited to
those who order copies in advance,
and, as such orders cannot be
placed once the book is on the
press, the business managment will
be forced to conclude its campaign
very shortly. For this purpose, the
Hullabaloo staff is emphasizing
more and more the interest which
all students of the University should
have in the book, both because of
its contents, and as a matter of increasing its circulation for the time
when they themselves will be the
publishers. The committee from
whom subscription blanks may be
obtained consists of Vickers, McDowell and Hayes.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 22, 1916.
DEAN PRAISES STUDENT CORPS

TO CLASH IN TWO CONTESTS

CLUB TO ORGANIZE IN FALL

Review on Homewood Campus Shows
Remarkable Progress--Both Dean
Brush and Dr. Abercrombie
Commend Spirit of Men.

Sophs and Freshies Plan to Hold Annual Baseball and Lacrosse Games on
Successive Days Freshman Baseball Team Defeats Dunham.

Hopkins Polity Club to Begin Year With
Large Enrollment Leaders Decide
This Season Too Far Advanced
for Actual Work.

The final drill for this year of
the Hopkins Cadet Corps was held
last Monday, May i, on the
campus in front of Gilman Hall,
before Dean Brush, Dr. Abercrombie, Mr. Kistler and a number of
the relatives and friends of the
students. After a short drill, remarkable for its precise execution,
Dean Brush and Dr. Abercrombie
addressed the company, both praising it for its spirit in keeping up the
training in the face of so many
disadvantages.
For several weeks the men had
been practicing diligently on the
company movements and consequently the drill last Monday was
executed with scarcely a flaw. Linton, graduate; Minslow-Baxley,
'17; Thompson, 'iv; Chesley,'17,
and Darley, '17, had charge of the
company, one after the other, all
displaying unusual ability in commanding. After the company was
put through first the simple and
then the more involved movements,
the command "pass in review" was
given. Immediately squads right
was executed and the company in
two straight lines passed by the reviewers with "eyes right," the
salute in marching.
After. three quarters of an hour
of drill the company was halted
before the reviewing stand, the
steps in front of Gilman Hall.
While the men stood at rest, the
Dean thanked them for the praiseworthy support that they had given
the company. 'Never," he said,
"have Hopkins men .displayed
greater loyalty to their Alma Mater
than you have, and you are to be
commended for it. We who have
watched you have been greatly impressed by the spirit you have displayed and by the importance of
the movement and we shall do
everything in our power to make
it a success next year."
Dean Brush went on to say that
he had been informed by Captain
Kirk, the officer of the War Department who inspected, the company at one of its first drills, that
the reason no officer had been sent
to Hopkins was because of the
Mexican situation. Moreover, the
equipment had not been supplied.
He could do more for us, said
Captain Kirk, as soon as the new
bill dealing with military training
at colleges has been passed.
Dean Brush went on to say that
provision will be made to prevent
the hours for drill from conflicting
with training for the various college teams. The schedule has not
as yet been arranged, but the time
for the drills will be selected in
such a way that the candidates for
the teams can also have a chance
to practice.
Dr. Abercrombie then spoke to
the men and, like the Dean, thanked

The freshmen and sophomores
will clash on both lacrosse field and
baseball diamond the early part of
this week. The ball game will take
place Tuesday, while, the rival
twelves will meet Wednesday afternoon. Both classes have been
practicing faithfully and two hard
fought and well played games
should take place. The sophomores
seem to have an edge on the freshmen in lacrosse, but the first-year
men are counting on Wasserman,
the star twirler of last year's City
College nine, to trim the sophies
on the diamond.
On the sophomore lacrosse team
are F. Sutton, Aleck Wolfe, Dick
Woodward, Bobby Hoffman, Bill
Swartz and Hank Chalmers, all of
whom have had Varsity experience,
while the freshmen have Ferdie
Meyer, Dutch Schmidt and Herb
Baxley, as well as several men who
showed up well on last year's City
College team.
There is but one underclassman,
Stewart Egerton, on the 'Varsity
baseball team, although Randall
and Cort for the sophomores, and
Marshall and Wasserman for the
freshmen, are on the squad.
The freshmen nine defeated the
Boys Latin School last week 10 to
8. Dunham was ahead until the
ninth inning, when the freshmen
scored four runs and tied the count.
In the tenth they crossed the plate
twice again. The score:

The International Polity Club.
By Bruce Williams.

The inauguration last week of an
International Polity Club in this
University was an event that made
a notable contribution to the University life. The significance of
the undertaking is two-fold: it announces the introduction here of
yet another phase of student activity apart from the regular academic pursuits, and it places Johns
Hopkins among the other leading
American universities whose student-bodies are manifesting an
earnest and investigating attitude
towards world-politics.
Within the past two years there
has developed in the student-bodies
of America a movement for the
study of international relations and
for the promotion of international
polity that is widespread in its extent and impressive by reason of
its influence. The propaganda
forces of the nation, organized outside of the educational institutions,
are continually turning ta these as
the most fruitful field for the development of particular ideas. None
have met with such response as
have those which attempt to instruct in the fundamental principles upon. which rest the relations
of one nation with another and
which seek to promote a rational
conception of national rights. The
essential sanity of such a program,
divested as it is of any particular
vagary, has won widespread recognition.
The organizations in the universities have in most • cases taken the
form of International Polity Clubs,
established and fostered Under the
guidance of the American Asscciation for International Conciliation. This Association, which
is maintained under the Carnegie Endowment for International
Peace, is perhaps the most authoritative organization in the world
today that endeavors to give a
popular interpretation to problems
of international import and which
emphasizes this ultimate possibility
of conciliation between nations
where their peoples have been .educated to an understanding of their
respective rights and duties. During
the year 1915, the Association provided for the Polity Clubs a series
of six lectures conducted by international experts on the following topics: History of the Peace
Movement, the Psychology of War
and Peace, Economic Factors in
Modern Internationalism, Some
Biological and Racial Aspects of

War, the Place of Force in Modern
Civilization, the Future Outcome
and World Organization.
It is unnecessary to emphasize
the trenchant interest of such
topics as these. They impress their
significance on the most casual observer of current problems and to
the mind dissatisfied with the
superficial conclusions of the day,
they are suggestive of intricate
and underlying .causes. In the
study and discussion of such topics
there unquestionably will be found
a more satisfactory state of mind
than that produced by the protagonists of the "peace" or "preparedness" issues as they harangue
their ideas before the nation today.
The present, almost inpulsive,
move towards internationalism is
unmistakable evidence of a new era.
At Washington this week convents
the League to Enforce Peace, presided over by President Lowell of
Harvard and sponsored by exPresident Taft, and the program
of which, if ever adopted, would
commit America to a course unprecedented and venturesome as
compared to its traditional policy.
Whether the nation shall maintain
itself in a strong defensive isolation or merge its interests into a
protective international alliance is
an issue that compels attention and
demands a decision in the not far
distant future. To study such
problems as this one, is manifestly
stimulating and beneficial to any
student group.
The International Polity Club at
Hopkins will follow the policy
usually pursued by such organizations of its kind. It will enlist in
the organization such men as evince
an earnest and sympathetic interest
in the study of international relationships. At intervals during the
next academic year the club will
attempt to bring to the University
a number of speakers who are especially qualified to discuss international problems. At a time -when
the foreign policy of the nation is
the .most engrossing public issue,
this club will doubtless receive a
vigorous and enthusiastic support.
One of the oldest schools for girls
on the American continent is the
Colegio de la Paz in Mexico City.
This was founded by wealthy Spaniards in 1732 for the benefit of the
children of the poorer classes. The
building was designed after the
royal palace in Madrid and covers
nearly five acres of ground. The
original name was the Colegio de
San Ignacio. About eight hundred
girls are usually in the college 'under a staff of 45 teachers.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 22, 1916.
REMOVAL TO HOMEWOOD BEGINS

PHILOLOGICAL ASSOCIATION
DISCUSSES EMPEROR CLAUDIUS

Parts of Library and Specimens from Scientific Departments Already Starting
to New Locations—All Changes to
Be Made by End of Summer.

With the removal of the library
and the beginning of the transportation of the scientific departments,
the Hopkins change of site is well
under way.
For over three years the heads
of the various departments have
been planning how the removal to
Homewood could best be accomplished, and it is due to the foresightedness of these arrangements
that, despite the magnitude of the
• problems involved, the change is
proceeding so smoothly that it is
passing practically unnoticed.
A good part of the library has
already been taken from its shelves
land is being placed in the new stacks
at Homewood. It is in this department that the work must be finished first, as all the books must be
removed before the opening of the
summer school on July 5. The
works on political science and
edonomy have been the first to go,
and the summer classes which will
occupy the rooms now used for
seminaries will not be disturbed by
crating or hauling.
The biological department has
also been quietly preparing the most
valuable of its specimens for transportation,. and the remainder of the
change will take place early in the
corning vacation. The specimens
in the geological laboratories present more intricate 'problems, both
because of their greater bulk and because of the value attached to even
some of the smaller . specimens.
However, most of these problems
have been solved, and the- department is ready to begin the removal
as soon as the word is given.
While no definite date can as yet
be given for the completion of the
change of location, it is confidently
expec'ed by those in charge that,
when the University reassembles
in the fall, all the necessary arrangements will have been made,
and that Hopkins by that time will
be formally installed in its new
home.

"A Diagnosis of the Case of the
Emperor Claudius" was the title
of an article read by Mr. T. D. C.
Ruth before-the University Philological Association last Friday.
Mr. Ruth endeavored to prove that
Claudius was not insane, as is generally believed, but was afflicted
with a form of infantile paralysis.
Both the mental and the physical
defects of Claudius, he showed, correspond exactly to the effects of
this disease. Although he deplored
the modern tendency to glorify all
the dark characters of history, Mr.
Ruth pointed out that Claudius was
never really understood, either by
those of his own time or by future
historians.
Claudius was naturally extremely
nervous and of delicate constitution. Being hated and neglected by
his own mother and by his other
relatives, he was left to the care of
pedagogues, women and slaves.
The effect of this, Mr. Ruth
pointed out, was that he grew up
a recluse until, after the murder
of the undoubtedly insane Caligula, he became emperor. He was
utterly unfitted and untrained to
hold such power and, consequently,
gained the unearned reputation of
being insane.
After the reading of this article,
it was announced that the new
president of the Philological Association, Professor Bloomfield, would
make his inaugural address at the
next meeting.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY. 22, 1916.

FUND FOR GAS PLANT COMPLETED

NEW COURSES TO BE OFFERED

Over $3,000 Now Available for Con
struction of Plantfor Use of Engineering Departmentin Studying Problems of Gas Industry.

Hopkins Summer School Will Have Many
New Courses, Two Dealing With Present War -Most Important of Last
Year's Subjects Retained.

A fund of $3,300 has been completed for the building of an experimental coal gas plant to be used
in connection with the engineering
department of the Johns Hopkins
University. It has been announced
that the engineering department
is ready to proceed with the construction on the plans drawn up by
Professor Thomas of the Civil Engineering division and Captain
Wagner, chief engineer of the
Bartlett Hayward Company, and
that the plant may be in operation
by next September.
The object of the plant is to attack those problems of the gas industry which involve the recovery
of by-products necessary for use in
the manufacture of dye-stuffs,
medicinals and explosives. The
solving of these problems would
make this country independent of
the supply from foreign countries
which has been cut off because of
the war.
During the past year, a course
on this subject has been given by
Captain Wagner to a class of 17
graduate students, and has been
accompanied by comprehensive
laboratory work. Great interest
has been displayed in the course not
only in the University itself among
the local scientific students, but
also by colleges throughout the
country. Many of these institutions have written to the head of
the Hopkins department asking
whether the course is to be continued in coming years.

There will be several new courses
offered at this year's summer
school. One of the most interesting of these is "The Money Market and the European War," to be
given by Dr. Whitney. The course
is especially designed for those who
have had some previous knowledge
of political economy or who are
familiar with the fundaments of
banking and finance. It can be
taken for graduate credit. A discussion of monetary laws, an analysis of the banking systems in the
chief money markets of the world
and a study•of the principles of foreign exchange will be among the
important points taken up. Special
emphasis will be laid on the effects
of the war on international exchanges as the result of the accumulations of gold, the selling of
securities and the issuing of paper
money.
Another of Dr. Whitney's courses
will be "Public Finance.'" In this
the methods of collecting public revenue and taxes and of expenditures will be critically analyzed.
Professor Wood, of the Department of German, will lecture on the
subject of "Swabian and Austrian
Poets in the First Half of the Nineteenth Century." The period will
range from the life of Uhland up
to that of Morike. Professor Gay,
of Goucher College, will give one
course in the history of English
Literature from 160o to 1775, taking up the lives and works of Milton, Dryden, Pope and Johnson,
and other authors of their age and
school.
Another course dealing with the

The seniors are now busy making plans for their class week,
which already promises to be one
of the best in the history of the
University. Exercises will begin
on Thursday, June 8, the day after
the last examinations, with the
Senior Prom in McCoy Hall at 8
P. M. Bagley, Woodward and
Hardy have arranged for this affair
and while all plans have not yet
been completed, enough has been
done to assure the class that the
prom will be one worthy of Hopkins tradition.
On,Friday, the 9th, will come the
"Senior Party," for seniors only,
which will probably be held at
Thompson's, near River View, as
is the custom. This, however, is
not definite, as Luke Vickers, chairman of the Party Committee, has
not yet announced the final arrangements.
In addition to these events, the
seniors are planning to hold a boat
ride on Saturday, the loth, to which
all students will be invited.
Monday, June 12, is Class Day,
and for this occasion Fricke, Hale
and Primrose have arranged a
splendid program. At 2 o'clock
a minstrel show will be given in
McCoy Hall, at which the University quartet will sing. This will be
followed by the awarding of the
"H's" won in spring sports and in
debating, and by short addresses
by President Goodnow, Dr. Latane,
the honorary president of the
Senior Class, and by President
Thomas J. Tingley. Following this,
a dance will probably be held from
4 to 6.
On the afternoon of Tuesday, the
13th, will come the conferring of
degrees at the Academy of Music.
In the evening the faculty of the
University will give a reception in
honor of the Senior Class.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 22, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HOPKINS WINS SECOND PLACE

ST. JOHN'S NINE VICTORIOUS

'VARSITY WINS BOTH MATCHES

FOOTBALL SCHEDULE ANNOUNCED

Track Team Finishes After B. A. A. in
South Atlantic Meet-Hall and Connolly Capture Championships.
Straus Next Captain.

Wins Last Baseball Game of Season,
After Hard Struggle, by Score of 2
to 1-Phythyon Pitches Well
for Johns Hopkins.

Defeats University of Michigan by Score
of 4-2 and Georgetown University
6-0-Hopkins Men Show
Fine Form.

Presents Few Changes From That of
Last Year-M. A. C. Game to
Take Place Again on
Thanksgiving.

The Baltimore Athletic Association captured the team trophy in the
games held by the South Atlantic
Division, Amateur Athletic Union,
on Homewood Field last Friday,
Hopkins taking second among the
ten organizations represented. The
Baltimore Athletic Association had
a very large number of competitors
entered under their colors, and with
he stellar work of their "giant"
Tommy McDonagh, supported by
a large number of lesser satelites,
they piled up 47 points while Hopkins was making 34. In the longer
runs Hopkins had a decided advantage, but their opponents'
strength in the hurdles and weights
gave them the lead.
McDonagh was easily the star
of the meet with 19 points to his
credit, made in five events, but Connolly of Hopkins also earned his
share of glory, taking part in six
events, hurrying back and forth accross the field so as not to miss
his turn at anything, and securing
places in five contests with a total
of ii. It was "Husky's" last appearance for Hopkins, ending a
career of four years' faithful work
and consistent point-winning.
Two records of the Association
were smashed and one equalled in
the afternoon's performance, not
to speak of a new Hopkins mark
being set in the half-mile run. In
the last-named event, Hall went
out at a pretty good clip from the
start, his tracks being closely followed by Chipman of Maryland
Agricultural College, who kept the
Hopkins man up to his pace. The
time, 2 minutes I 2-5 seconds, is
four-fifths of second better than the
old mark, set by E. S. Woodruff,
a graduate student, in 19oo.
Tommy McDonagh was responsible :for disturbing two low
marks. In the high hurdles he
cl:pped a fifth off, by covering the
ground in 15 3-5 seconds, and in
the low hurdles he equalled a
former performance by tearing
through in 25 4-5. A third association mark was upset by Weidman, Georgetown's sensational
pole-vaulter. After raising the
standards by th use of some hurdles, and putting the bar on the
very top .of the posts, he cleared
12 feet with a terrific leap.
After the meet, which is the last
on the schedule for the season, the
team elected Harry Straus, '17,
captain of next year's team. Straus
has been a hard worker for three
years at Hopkins, and prior to that

With both pitchers in rare form
and pitching' air-tight ball, St.
John's was just barely able to nose
out Hopkins 2 10 I, at Homewood,
on Saturday afternoon. The game
was exceptionally fast, Captain Ewing's work around third base and
on the paths being the feature of
the game.
In the first inning Hopkins
scored. Ewing's speed was responsible for the only tally made by
the Black and Blue during the
game. He drew a base on balls,
and then stole second. Tucker's
error of Hobbs' easy grounder gave
Ewing a chance to go to third.
Then the Hopkins captain and
Hobbs pulled a double steal, Ewing being safe at home and Hobbs
resting securely on second.
St. John's won the game in the
second inning. Freeny and Polk
each drew a base on balls. Then
Siebold threw the ball over the
second baseman's head in his attempt to prevent the men from
making a double steal. Freeny
took home on the play. Elzey then
came across with a long two-bagger
and Polk ran home with the winning run.
The rest of the game was hardfought, but resulted in no scoring.
Ewing stopped a St. John's rally
in the eighth by making a beautiful catch of Burgess' liner and
doubling up Elzey at first. Again
in the ninth, Ewing brought the
spectators to their feet by running
over to the fence and catching Jarman's foul.
In the ninth inning Hopkins had
a chance to even up the score.
Howell took first on Freeny's error
and then stole second. The Hopkins rooters had their hopes raised
for a few moments, but Siebold
fanned at three of Tucker's curves,
making the third out.
If Hopkins had won this game
it would have given them a good
claim on the state championship,
but as it is, St. John's has won this
honor from Hopkins for the first
time in years.

The Johns Hopkins tennis team
added two more victories to its list
by defeating the University of
Michigan and Georgetown teams
on Friday and Saturday respectively.
During the first part of the
Michigan match it seemed as if the
visitors were going to have an easy
time of it, but a brilliant rally by
the Hopkins men succeeded in turning the tables and resulted in a 4
to 2 victory for the 'Varsity. The
GeorgetoWn match was easily won
by Hopkins, the score being 6 to O.
The scores of the matches are as
follows:
Hopkins vs. University of Michigan, 4-2.

beat Sherwood, 3-6, 6-0, 6-4.

The football schedule for next fall
has been definitely announced by
Manager Davis. Since last fall,
rumors have been spread broa‘dcast that some of the big college
teams would be seen in action on
Homewood field during the 1916
football season, but these rumors
have been without foundation.
Hopkins will play practically the
same teams this year that it did
last.
The management is of the opinion that before Hopkins should attempt to move up the scale into the
realm of the big college teams, it
should have at least another season's experience against local teams.
In other words, the management
does not want to book games with
the big colleges until it feels confident that the Black and Blue can
make a good showing against them..
As soon as Hopkins has successfully shown to all its permanent
superiority over the Maryland
teams, no time will be lost in arranging games with the best teams
in the East. As was the case last
year, the Maryland Agricultural
College will be seen at Homewood
on Thanksgiving Day, and St.
Johns will be played the Saturday
before Thanksgiving: All the
games of the season are to be
played at Homewood.

years, and has had long experience
in the business administration of
the paper.
With this meeting, the resignations of Frederick K. Bell and G.
Franklin Ludington, both of the
Class of 1916, went into effect.
These men were both elected in
February, 1915, and for over .a
year have rendered valuable service as associate editors.

DEBATING COUNCIL TO LET
TRIANGULAR AGREEMENT WAIT

Although it was at first thought
advisable to have the triangular debating agreement between this
University and the Universities of
North Carolina and Virginia signed
this year, the Debating Council has
informally decided that, in view of
the extremely friendly relations between the three institutions which
four years of debating contests
have brought about, the annual
compact can wait for formal ratification until next season.
At Class Day, the eight members
of the two victorious teams of this
year will be presented, with the
blue "H," the official Hopkins
award for debating.

HULLABALOO TO BE OUT JUNE 1
Final Proofs Have Been Corrected, and
Book Now Ready for Pre!s—Business Staff Waging Subscription Campaign.

The 1916 Hullabaloo will appear
on or about June 1. The first proofs
for the book are already in the
hands of Editor-in-chief Tingley,
and the business arrangements for
the payment and distribution of the
issue are rapidly nearing completion.
In its final form, the Hullabaloo
will have nearly 300 pages. The
dummy for the entire issue has
long ago been made and presented
to the printer, and the reading of
proof was the last stage in the editorial work. This reading came to
end on last Friday morning, and
the time before the book is issued
will now be measured entirely by
the period required for the mechanical processes of making corrections,
running the forms off the press,
and binding the separate sheets.
Judging by the proofs, this year's
Hullabaloo will be one of the best
ever produced by a Hopkins class.
It is highly original, both in arrangement and in material; the
art work is of an exceptionally high
caliber; and, even in the imperfect
appearance presented by unbound
sheets, the contents of the book
promise to be unusually interesting,
not only to the members of the
Senior Class, but to the University
as a whole.
The business staff is now busily
engaged in collecting the debts still
outstanding, and in taking every
possible means to guarantee a large
circulation. Every member of the
graduating class has already subscribed for at least one copy, many
of them for more, and a large number of underclassmen have signified their intention of buying the
book. It is in the support of the
latter element that the Hullabaloo
is now particularly interested. The
edition is to be strictly limited to
those who order copies in advance,
and, as such orders cannot be
placed once the book is on the
press, the business managment will
be forced to conclude its campaign
very shortly. For this purpose, the
Hullabaloo staff is emphasizing
more and more the interest which
all students of the University should
have in the book, both because of
its contents, and as a matter of increasing its circulation for the time
when they themselves will be the
publishers. The committee from
whom subscription blanks may be
obtained consists of Vickers, McDowell and Hayes.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 22, 1916.
DEAN PRAISES STUDENT CORPS

TO CLASH IN TWO CONTESTS

CLUB TO ORGANIZE IN FALL

Review on Homewood Campus Shows
Remarkable Progress--Both Dean
Brush and Dr. Abercrombie
Commend Spirit of Men.

Sophs and Freshies Plan to Hold Annual Baseball and Lacrosse Games on
Successive Days Freshman Baseball Team Defeats Dunham.

Hopkins Polity Club to Begin Year With
Large Enrollment Leaders Decide
This Season Too Far Advanced
for Actual Work.

The final drill for this year of
the Hopkins Cadet Corps was held
last Monday, May i, on the
campus in front of Gilman Hall,
before Dean Brush, Dr. Abercrombie, Mr. Kistler and a number of
the relatives and friends of the
students. After a short drill, remarkable for its precise execution,
Dean Brush and Dr. Abercrombie
addressed the company, both praising it for its spirit in keeping up the
training in the face of so many
disadvantages.
For several weeks the men had
been practicing diligently on the
company movements and consequently the drill last Monday was
executed with scarcely a flaw. Linton, graduate; Minslow-Baxley,
'17; Thompson, 'iv; Chesley,'17,
and Darley, '17, had charge of the
company, one after the other, all
displaying unusual ability in commanding. After the company was
put through first the simple and
then the more involved movements,
the command "pass in review" was
given. Immediately squads right
was executed and the company in
two straight lines passed by the reviewers with "eyes right," the
salute in marching.
After. three quarters of an hour
of drill the company was halted
before the reviewing stand, the
steps in front of Gilman Hall.
While the men stood at rest, the
Dean thanked them for the praiseworthy support that they had given
the company. 'Never," he said,
"have Hopkins men .displayed
greater loyalty to their Alma Mater
than you have, and you are to be
commended for it. We who have
watched you have been greatly impressed by the spirit you have displayed and by the importance of
the movement and we shall do
everything in our power to make
it a success next year."
Dean Brush went on to say that
he had been informed by Captain
Kirk, the officer of the War Department who inspected, the company at one of its first drills, that
the reason no officer had been sent
to Hopkins was because of the
Mexican situation. Moreover, the
equipment had not been supplied.
He could do more for us, said
Captain Kirk, as soon as the new
bill dealing with military training
at colleges has been passed.
Dean Brush went on to say that
provision will be made to prevent
the hours for drill from conflicting
with training for the various college teams. The schedule has not
as yet been arranged, but the time
for the drills will be selected in
such a way that the candidates for
the teams can also have a chance
to practice.
Dr. Abercrombie then spoke to

College nine, to trim the sophies

Woodward, Bobby Hoffman, Bill

Stewart Egerton, on the 'Varsity
baseball team, although Randall
and Cort for the sophomores, and

The International Polity Club.
By Bruce Williams.

The inauguration last week of an
International Polity Club in this
University was an event that made
a notable contribution to the University life. The significance of
the undertaking is two-fold: it announces the introduction here of
yet another phase of student activity apart from the regular academic pursuits, and it places Johns
Hopkins among the other leading
American universities whose student-bodies are manifesting an
earnest and investigating attitude
towards world-politics.
Within the past two years there
has developed in the student-bodies
of America a movement for the
study of international relations and
for the promotion of international
polity that is widespread in its extent and impressive by reason of
its influence. The propaganda
forces of the nation, organized outside of the educational institutions,
are continually turning ta these as
the most fruitful field for the development of particular ideas. None
have met with such response as
have those which attempt to instruct in the fundamental principles upon. which rest the relations
of one nation with another and
which seek to promote a rational
conception of national rights. The
essential sanity of such a program,
divested as it is of any particular
vagary, has won widespread recognition.
The organizations in the universities have in most • cases taken the
form of International Polity Clubs,
established and fostered Under the
guidance of the American Asscciation for International Conciliation. This Association, which
is maintained under the Carnegie Endowment for International
Peace, is perhaps the most authoritative organization in the world
today that endeavors to give a
popular interpretation to problems
of international import and which
emphasizes this ultimate possibility
of conciliation between nations
where their peoples have been .educated to an understanding of their
respective rights and duties. During
the year 1915, the Association provided for the Polity Clubs a series
of six lectures conducted by international experts on the following topics: History of the Peace
Movement, the Psychology of War
and Peace, Economic Factors in
Modern Internationalism, Some
Biological and Racial Aspects of

War, the Place of Force in Modern
Civilization, the Future Outcome
and World Organization.
It is unnecessary to emphasize
the trenchant interest of such
topics as these. They impress their
significance on the most casual observer of current problems and to
the mind dissatisfied with the
superficial conclusions of the day,
they are suggestive of intricate
and underlying .causes. In the
study and discussion of such topics
there unquestionably will be found
a more satisfactory state of mind
than that produced by the protagonists of the "peace" or "preparedness" issues as they harangue
their ideas before the nation today.
The present, almost inpulsive,
move towards internationalism is
unmistakable evidence of a new era.
At Washington this week convents
the League to Enforce Peace, presided over by President Lowell of
Harvard and sponsored by exPresident Taft, and the program
of which, if ever adopted, would
commit America to a course unprecedented and venturesome as
compared to its traditional policy.
Whether the nation shall maintain
itself in a strong defensive isolation or merge its interests into a
protective international alliance is
an issue that compels attention and
demands a decision in the not far
distant future. To study such
problems as this one, is manifestly
stimulating and beneficial to any
student group.
The International Polity Club at
Hopkins will follow the policy
usually pursued by such organizations of its kind. It will enlist in
the organization such men as evince
an earnest and sympathetic interest
in the study of international relationships. At intervals during the
next academic year the club will
attempt to bring to the University
a number of speakers who are especially qualified to discuss international problems. At a time -when
the foreign policy of the nation is
the .most engrossing public issue,
this club will doubtless receive a
vigorous and enthusiastic support.
One of the oldest schools for girls
on the American continent is the
Colegio de la Paz in Mexico City.
This was founded by wealthy Spaniards in 1732 for the benefit of the
children of the poorer classes. The
building was designed after the
royal palace in Madrid and covers
nearly five acres of ground. The
original name was the Colegio de
San Ignacio. About eight hundred
girls are usually in the college 'under a staff of 45 teachers.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 22, 1916.
REMOVAL TO HOMEWOOD BEGINS

PHILOLOGICAL ASSOCIATION
DISCUSSES EMPEROR CLAUDIUS

Parts of Library and Specimens from Scientific Departments Already Starting
to New Locations—All Changes to
Be Made by End of Summer.

With the removal of the library
and the beginning of the transportation of the scientific departments,
the Hopkins change of site is well
under way.
For over three years the heads
of the various departments have
been planning how the removal to
Homewood could best be accomplished, and it is due to the foresightedness of these arrangements
that, despite the magnitude of the
• problems involved, the change is
proceeding so smoothly that it is
passing practically unnoticed.
A good part of the library has
already been taken from its shelves
land is being placed in the new stacks
at Homewood. It is in this department that the work must be finished first, as all the books must be
removed before the opening of the
summer school on July 5. The
works on political science and
edonomy have been the first to go,
and the summer classes which will
occupy the rooms now used for
seminaries will not be disturbed by
crating or hauling.
The biological department has
also been quietly preparing the most
valuable of its specimens for transportation,. and the remainder of the
change will take place early in the
corning vacation. The specimens
in the geological laboratories present more intricate 'problems, both
because of their greater bulk and because of the value attached to even
some of the smaller . specimens.
However, most of these problems
have been solved, and the- department is ready to begin the removal
as soon as the word is given.
While no definite date can as yet
be given for the completion of the
change of location, it is confidently
expec'ed by those in charge that,
when the University reassembles
in the fall, all the necessary arrangements will have been made,
and that Hopkins by that time will
be formally installed in its new
home.

"A Diagnosis of the Case of the
Emperor Claudius" was the title
of an article read by Mr. T. D. C.
Ruth before-the University Philological Association last Friday.
Mr. Ruth endeavored to prove that
Claudius was not insane, as is generally believed, but was afflicted
with a form of infantile paralysis.
Both the mental and the physical
defects of Claudius, he showed, correspond exactly to the effects of
this disease. Although he deplored
the modern tendency to glorify all
the dark characters of history, Mr.
Ruth pointed out that Claudius was
never really understood, either by
those of his own time or by future
historians.
Claudius was naturally extremely
nervous and of delicate constitution. Being hated and neglected by
his own mother and by his other
relatives, he was left to the care of
pedagogues, women and slaves.
The effect of this, Mr. Ruth
pointed out, was that he grew up
a recluse until, after the murder
of the undoubtedly insane Caligula, he became emperor. He was
utterly unfitted and untrained to
hold such power and, consequently,
gained the unearned reputation of
being insane.
After the reading of this article,
it was announced that the new
president of the Philological Association, Professor Bloomfield, would
make his inaugural address at the
next meeting.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY. 22, 1916.

FUND FOR GAS PLANT COMPLETED

NEW COURSES TO BE OFFERED

Over $3,000 Now Available for Con
struction of Plantfor Use of Engineering Departmentin Studying Problems of Gas Industry.

Hopkins Summer School Will Have Many
New Courses, Two Dealing With Present War -Most Important of Last
Year's Subjects Retained.

A fund of $3,300 has been completed for the building of an experimental coal gas plant to be used
in connection with the engineering
department of the Johns Hopkins
University. It has been announced
that the engineering department
is ready to proceed with the construction on the plans drawn up by
Professor Thomas of the Civil Engineering division and Captain
Wagner, chief engineer of the
Bartlett Hayward Company, and
that the plant may be in operation
by next September.
The object of the plant is to attack those problems of the gas industry which involve the recovery
of by-products necessary for use in
the manufacture of dye-stuffs,
medicinals and explosives. The
solving of these problems would
make this country independent of
the supply from foreign countries
which has been cut off because of
the war.
During the past year, a course
on this subject has been given by
Captain Wagner to a class of 17
graduate students, and has been
accompanied by comprehensive
laboratory work. Great interest
has been displayed in the course not
only in the University itself among
the local scientific students, but
also by colleges throughout the
country. Many of these institutions have written to the head of
the Hopkins department asking
whether the course is to be continued in coming years.

There will be several new courses
offered at this year's summer
school. One of the most interesting of these is "The Money Market and the European War," to be
given by Dr. Whitney. The course
is especially designed for those who
have had some previous knowledge
of political economy or who are
familiar with the fundaments of
banking and finance. It can be
taken for graduate credit. A discussion of monetary laws, an analysis of the banking systems in the
chief money markets of the world
and a study•of the principles of foreign exchange will be among the
important points taken up. Special
emphasis will be laid on the effects
of the war on international exchanges as the result of the accumulations of gold, the selling of
securities and the issuing of paper
money.
Another of Dr. Whitney's courses
will be "Public Finance.'" In this
the methods of collecting public revenue and taxes and of expenditures will be critically analyzed.
Professor Wood, of the Department of German, will lecture on the
subject of "Swabian and Austrian
Poets in the First Half of the Nineteenth Century." The period will
range from the life of Uhland up
to that of Morike. Professor Gay,
of Goucher College, will give one
course in the history of English
Literature from 160o to 1775, taking up the lives and works of Milton, Dryden, Pope and Johnson,
and other authors of their age and
school.

The seniors are now busy making plans for their class week,
which already promises to be one
of the best in the history of the
University. Exercises will begin
on Thursday, June 8, the day after
the last examinations, with the
Senior Prom in McCoy Hall at 8
P. M. Bagley, Woodward and
Hardy have arranged for this affair
and while all plans have not yet
been completed, enough has been
done to assure the class that the
prom will be one worthy of Hopkins tradition.
On,Friday, the 9th, will come the
"Senior Party," for seniors only,
which will probably be held at
Thompson's, near River View, as
is the custom. This, however, is
not definite, as Luke Vickers, chairman of the Party Committee, has
not yet announced the final arrangements.
In addition to these events, the
seniors are planning to hold a boat
ride on Saturday, the loth, to which
all students will be invited.
Monday, June 12, is Class Day,
and for this occasion Fricke, Hale
and Primrose have arranged a
splendid program. At 2 o'clock
a minstrel show will be given in
McCoy Hall, at which the University quartet will sing. This will be
followed by the awarding of the
"H's" won in spring sports and in
debating, and by short addresses
by President Goodnow, Dr. Latane,
the honorary president of the
Senior Class, and by President
Thomas J. Tingley. Following this,
a dance will probably be held from
4 to 6.
On the afternoon of Tuesday, the
13th, will come the conferring of
degrees at the Academy of Music.
In the evening the faculty of the
University will give a reception in
honor of the Senior Class.
